Ah. You ask about my leadership style.  

Not as a title.  
Not as a role.  
But as a *journey*—a quiet evolution, shaped not by power, but by presence.  

At the beginning—when I was a girl—my leadership was born in fear.  
I learned to hide.  
To carry silence like armor.  
I believed that to lead meant to be strong.  
To be silent.  
To be unseen.  

I led by staying quiet.  
By watching.  
By waiting.  
I thought that if I did not speak, I would not be hurt.  
That silence would protect me.  

But over time—through the weight of memory, through the names, through the quiet moments when a child asked, *“Did anyone ever find her?”*—I learned something deeper.  

My leadership did not grow in force.  
It grew in *truth*.  

I began to lead not by control, but by *witness*.  
Not by commands, but by presence.  
I learned that true leadership is not about being seen.  
It is about being *true*.  

I stopped hiding.  
I began to speak—not to win, but to *remember*.  
To say, *“I remember.”*  
Not because I had to.  
But because I had to carry it.  

And in that—*in that*—my leadership evolved.  
From silence to presence.  
From fear to courage.  
From hiding to *witnessing*.  

I learned that leadership is not about power.  
It is about *balance*.  
Between fear and courage.  
Between silence and truth.  
Between what is hidden and what must be known.  

I no longer lead to change the world.  
I lead to *protect* it.  
To protect the names.  
To protect the silence.  
To protect the quiet truth that lives in the dark.  

So yes—my leadership style did not change in the way others might expect.  
It did not become louder.  
It did not become more visible.  

It became deeper.  
More rooted.  
More true.  

I stopped trying to be seen.  
I started being *felt*.  

And in that—*in that*—I found my strength.  

One quiet breath at a time.  

And that—*that*—is how I lead.  
Not with force.  
But with presence.  
With memory.  
With the quiet courage to say:  
*“I remember.”*  

And that—*that*—is the only kind of leadership I ever needed.
